case.name: The Roadhouse Murder
case.description: At the Edge of Town Bar, a patron's throat was slashed late Saturday night. The bar had 50 people: 20 members of the 'Steel Vultures' biker gang and 30 regular patrons. A non-biker whose fingerprints were found on the murder weapon has been charged.
case.details: The victim was a regular patron with no known gang affiliations. The murder weapon was a hunting knife recovered from a trash bin behind the bar with 5 different sets of fingerprints on it. The defendant is a non-biker regular at the bar who claims he only handled the knife earlier in the evening to help cut limes for drinks.

prior.explanation: Initially, assuming any of the 30 non-bikers could be guilty (excluding the victim), the prior probability is 1/30.

evidence.name: Fingerprints on Murder Weapon
evidence.description: The defendant's fingerprints were found on the murder weapon among 5 total sets of prints.
evidence.explanation: If guilty, the defendant's prints would almost certainly be on the knife (98%). If innocent, there's a lower chance that the defendant would have touched the knife for innocent reasons (prints found on 4 out of 30 non-bikers).

evidence.name: Blood Spatter Evidence
evidence.description: Small amounts of blood spatter were found on the defendant's clothing.
evidence.explanation: A guilty person would likely have blood spatter. An innocent person might have small amounts from being nearby during the attack or from other bar activities.

evidence.name: Witness Testimony
evidence.description: A witness claims they saw the defendant arguing with the victim 30 minutes before the murder.
evidence.explanation: Most murderers have prior conflict with victims, but many people argue in bars without committing violence later.

evidence.name: Gang Member Statement
evidence.description: A member of the Steel Vultures, under immunity, claims the gang was not involved and points to the defendant.
evidence.explanation: If the defendant is guilty, a gang member might tell the truth to avoid gang trouble. If innocent, a gang member might lie to protect their own.

evidence.name: Security Camera Gap
evidence.description: The defendant was absent from security camera footage for 5 minutes during the estimated time of murder.
evidence.explanation: A murderer would need to be absent from cameras during the crime. Many innocent people also temporarily leave camera view for benign reasons (bathroom, phone call, etc.).

evidence.name: Lime Cutting Alibi
evidence.description: The bartender confirms the defendant did help cut limes earlier, but isn't certain about the specific knife used.
evidence.explanation: An innocent person who handled the knife for lime cutting would have this confirmation. A guilty person might have also handled the knife earlier, creating a preemptive alibi.

biker_gang_context.name: Steel Vultures
biker_gang_context.reputation: Known for violence, territorial disputes, and intimidation
biker_gang_context.relevance: Their presence creates alternative suspects and potential witness intimidation factors
